thread.title: Rangers offseason issue No. 1: Is there enough starting pitching? If there isn't, whom Texas might target
thread.title_full: Rangers offseason issue No. 1: Is there enough starting pitching? If there isn't, whom Texas might target | Dallas Morning News

author: Evan Grant
title: Rangers offseason issue No. 1: Is there enough starting pitching? If there isn't, whom Texas might target
text:
The Rangers may have had a hard time sleeping after their season came to an abrupt end on Wednesday afternoon, but, regardless, it's time to put 2015 to bed.
And it's time to start focusing on 2016, because, well, the business of baseball never ends.
With that in mind, we'll spend the week looking at five major issues the Rangers will spend a significant amount of time trying to solve this winter:
Issue No. 1: Is there enough starting pitching?
This is always issue No. 1. And lest anybody forget it, just remember that the Rangers last winter added Yovani Gallardo to further reinforce a rotation that looked like an asset only to lose Yu Darvish and Derek Holland before the end of the first week of the season.
The Rangers go into the winter with an ace on hand in Cole Hamels and with another (Darvish) expected back by May. They expect continued improvement from Martin Perez as he goes into his second season post-Tommy John surgery. They still have no idea what to expect from Derek Holland, who can be awesome one game and awful the next. Chi Chi Gonzalez should be ready to assume a starter's spot full-time.
In a best-case scenario, that's a five-man pool. Seven if you want to go so far as to add Nick Martinez and Anthony Ranaudo. Consider this: Every AL team used at least eight starters in 2015.
The guys who might have added depth - Jake Thompson, Alec Asher and Jerad Eickhoff - were all dealt to Philadelphia in the Cole Hamels/Jake Diekman deal.
There are no guarantees on Colby Lewis, who led the staff in innings in 2015, or Yovani Gallardo, who ranked second. Both are free agents. The Rangers can't count on either to forego the best possible market prices to re-sign with Texas. That simply doesn't happen.
"I remember reading a Quote: a couple of years ago, 'I you don't have enough pitching in April you're almost definitely not going to have it in September','' Daniels said. "That's the case. So I would expect this winter, between Colby and Yovani and/or somebody outside the organization that we will look to add some stability to the rotation."
It does not mean the Rangers will jump in on Zack Greinke. They already have their share of $100 million commitments and Greinke is liable to command about 2.5 times that much. They will search for value, whether it's on the trade market, as they did with Gallardo last year, or in free agency.
The Rangers did try to gauge Oakland's interest last summer in dealing Sonny Gray and that might be a place for them to start again this year. Gray would cost a ton in player inventory, but his salary will be quite affordable for at least three years. On the free agent market, look for the Rangers to dabble more in the buy-low market on a guy like sinkerballer Doug Fister, who is coming off an awful year in Washington.
